title: Currently in a chapter 13 and are thinking of walking away from our home. what are the consequences?
question: how difficult is the process and will the payment amount (minus mortgage payment) be lowered? is it possible the amount will go up?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: You would need to file amended schedule I and J to reflect new or changed Income and expense depending on the amount of rent versus your mortgage payments your disposable amount of income will change. then you would need to file to amend your plan payments and depending on the fact that you were paying arrears through your plan then the amount changes because if you are surrendering the house then the trustee does not need to pay for the arrears through the plan. It is better to consult your attorney or run through numbers before you make your decision, You can always convert to a chapter 7 bankruptcy if you qualify to get rid of all your unsecured debt and get a discharge within few months, however you need to qualify and pass the means test.

You will need to submit a new budget & a modified Chapter 13 Plan. (No point in continuing to have the Trustee pay your mortgage arrearages if you aren't keeping the house!)

If your expenses have gone down, it is possible that the Trustee will want an increased plan payment. The Trustee requirements are very different throughout the country, so unless you speak to a local attorney familiar with the Chapter 13 Truste, it is difficult to say for sure.

It all depends. If your rent from whatever new place you move to is lower than the mortgage payments you gave up, then you would have increased disposable income. That could lead to a higher plan payment. However, if your payments were already stretched to make the plan work, then you might be able to lower payments to a reasonable amount.

It all depends on your income and expenses. It also depends on whether you were paying arrearages and how much. Talk to your (or an) attorney immediately before making any decisions.

Assuming your plan has been confirmed you will have to modify it. If you have been paying back unpaid mortgage payments (mortgage arrears) in the plan then the plan payment will be reduced. However, you might be required to file updated Schedules I & J and your plan payment might go up or down depending on what is left of your income after expenses. In other words, you might have more or less to pay the unsecured creditors who have filed claims. There might not even be a reason to stay in Chapter 13. You might be better off converting your case to C13 or even dismiss it. Both convert ion or dismissal are generally easily. Bankruptcy and particularly C13 should not be handled without either representation by an experienced bankruptcy attorney who practices in the area where your case is pending or at least advice by such an attorney before taking any action in the case. Mistakes are costly in bankruptcy as much as in other legal cases or, in my opinion more, and without competent recommendation or advice your likely to make serious mistakes.
